modName: Guide to a Beautiful and Stable Skyrim
summary: A guide for a beautiful, immersive, and stable Skyrim experience, that is constantly being tweaked and added onto.
descriptionHtml:
So, I made a list of mods for my boyfriend a couple weeks ago, because he wanted to start modding Skyrim and had no idea where to start. Since I spent something like 4 hours making that for him, I figured I would take that, and merge it with some other knowledge I have learned over the course of 7 years while testing my own mods.

This is constantly being evolved and added onto. If you think something is missing and should be added, let me know! But there is a chance I left it out on purpose.

---------

When I first started modding my game, I had a semi-potato PC. Not completely potato, but also not the best rig in the world. Due to that, I was constantly tweaking my ini settings, resizing textures, and disabling mods. A lot of reinstalls. A lot of trial and error. It was incredibly frustrating. Since that time, I obtained a much better rig, however it's a laptop... So still not the best in the world. I decided to keep a lot of my settings and tweaks, and now my game is more stable than it's ever been (with some exceptions).

This is not perfect! I am only human, after all... And I spend more time testing my textures than actually playing the game. This is not meant as a 'copy and paste' guide. I do not expect anyone to take literally everything I have listed here and using it. Of course, you can do that. But, as I said, it is not perfect and you may still experience some crashes or other issues. I do. But it is constantly being worked on!

----------

[b]I have color-coordinated all mod names by the following:

[color=#ff7700]Large Performance Impact[/color]
[color=#ffff00]Medium Performance Impact[/color]
[color=#00ffff]Low Performance Impact[/color]
[color=#00ff00]No Performance Impact[/color][/b] [i](that I know of)[/i]


[size=4][b]Third-Party Software You'll Need - [/b][/size]

[color=#00ffff][b]LOOT:[/b] [/color]Used for sorting your load order. A necessity!
[b][color=#00ffff]ModOrganizer: [/color][/b]ONLY USE MOD ORGANIZER! Nexus Mod Manager can corrupt your game folder pretty fast and cause a huge mess. Until they create their new mod manager, use MO.
[color=#00ffff][b]TES5edit:[/b] [/color]Does a lot of things. Allows for editing plugins, merging, compiling scripts, etc.
[b][color=#00ffff]MergePlugins:[/color][/b] Used to quickly and easily merge mods to allow for more room in your load order. Highly recommended. Read the guide below on how to use.
[b][color=#00ffff]Ordenador: [/color][/b]Used to resize textures, to save on VRAM. Read guide below.
[b][color=#00ffff]Configurator:[/color][/b] Used to easily tweak INI settings.



[b][size=4]"Required" Mods -[/size][/b]

[color=#00ffff][b]SKSE - Skyrim Script Extender[/b]:[/color] This is required for script mods to work. It also allows for more stability and other performance tweaks I have in this guide.
[color=#00ff00][b]SkyUI:[/b] [/color]Improves and adds onto the GUI. Also adds a lot of customizations and a "Mod Configuration" section. A requirement for many mods.
[color=#00ffff][b]UIExtensions:[/b] [/color]A requirement for many mods.
[color=#ffff00][b]HDT Physics Extension:[/b] [/color]Adds a physics engine to the game, allowing for mods to use physics on clothing and other such things. Does not add physics to everything automatically. Does not add a performance impact alone.
[b][color=#ffff00]HDT HighHeels System:[/color][/b] A requirement for armor mods that add high heels, which increases the actual height for the wearers. Does not add this to every armor automatically. Does not add a performance impact alone.
[b][color=#00ff00]XP32 Maximum Skeleton Extended - XMPSE: [/color][/b]Skeleton mod that is required for most body or armor mods. It allows for physics, weapon placement, and other goodies. It also comes with slider options if you use Racemenu.
[color=#00ff00][b]Racemenu: [/b][/color]Adds hundreds of sliders into the Character Creation, as well as body/hand/feet/face overlays, and a sculpting function that I feel doesn't get enough attention. See my video here for tips on how to use the sculpt function.
[b][color=#00ffff]ShowRaceMenu Precache Killer: [/color][/b]Necessary if you use a lot of hair mods. Keeps the game from crashing.
[color=#00ffff][b]Unofficial Skyrim Legendary Edition Patch: [/b][/color]
[color=#00ffff][b]Mfg Console: [/b][/color]Adds blinking and eye rotation to player character. Also adds information on items within the game.
[color=#00ff00][b]Fores New Idles in Skyrim - FNIS: [/b][/color]
[b][color=#00ffff]FNIS PCEA2 - Player Exclusive Animations:

[b][color=#00ffff]NetImmerse Override: [/color][/b]This may be redundant, as Racemenu, I believe, includes it. But just to be safe, I download it separately.
